document_title: Rectal prolapse: Pictures, signs and treatment
subsection_content:
At first, the patient may only notice a lump or swollen tissue protruding from the anus during bowel movements and can be pushed back inside with his hand. However, over time, the tumor/tissue may prolapse outside the anus permanently and cannot be pushed back inside.
Long-term rectal prolapse will occur more often when the patient coughs, sneezes or stands up. Sometimes, rectal prolapse may feel like “sitting on a ball” or like incomplete bowel movements.
In addition, rectal prolapse can also have other symptoms such as difficulty controlling bowel movements, bright red blood flowing from the rectum, discomfort and possibly constipation. (3)
subsection_title: sa truc trang.json. Symptoms of rectal prolapse
subsection_data:

Long-term rectal prolapse will occur more often when the patient coughs, sneezes or stands up. Sometimes, rectal prolapse may feel like “sitting on a ball” or like incomplete bowel movements.
In addition, rectal prolapse can also have other symptoms such as difficulty controlling bowel movements, bright red blood flowing from the rectum, discomfort and possibly constipation. (3)
